Biomass.Description:
These roots can be identified as the impressive use of biomass resources, year-round sunshine and
higher rainfall, combined with frugal lifestyle of her people and the small geographical expanse of the country.

These roots can be identified as the impressive use of biomass resources, year-round sunshine and
higher rainfall, combined with frugal lifestyle of her people and the small geographical expanse of the country.

2d Commercial supply of biomass and biomass-based fuel products will be doubled
to reach one million tonne per year for using industrial thermal applications and
households through the establishment of 20,000 hectares of biomass plantations
within the period 2020-2023as an initiative of SEA.Government land, soft
financing and other fiscal incentives will be offered to businesses that provide
fuel wood including dedicated energy plantations and other commercial plantations.

2d Commercial supply of biomass and biomass-based fuel products will be doubled
to reach one million tonne per year for using industrial thermal applications and
households through the establishment of 20,000 hectares of biomass plantations
within the period 2020-2023as an initiative of SEA.Government land, soft
financing and other fiscal incentives will be offered to businesses that provide
fuel wood including dedicated energy plantations and other commercial plantations.

2d Commercial supply of biomass and biomass-based fuel products will be doubled
to reach one million tonne per year for using industrial thermal applications and
households through the establishment of 20,000 hectares of biomass plantations
within the period 2020-2023as an initiative of SEA.Government land, soft
financing and other fiscal incentives will be offered to businesses that provide
fuel wood including dedicated energy plantations and other commercial plantations.

SEA shall ensure a minimum 5% penetration of improved
stoves using commercialised biomass fuels by 2021.

SEA shall ensure a minimum 5% penetration of improved
stoves using commercialised biomass fuels by 2021.

Processed, commercialized biomassbased fuels used in such stoves will be made widely available across the retail
market by creating an enabling environment.

Processed, commercialized biomassbased fuels used in such stoves will be made widely available across the retail
market by creating an enabling environment.

5c At least 10,000 hectare of unproductive land will be prescribed as biomass energy
development areas, and leased to developers by the SEA starting from 2020 over
a period of 5 years to develop as commercial timber cum fuel wood plantations.

5c At least 10,000 hectare of unproductive land will be prescribed as biomass energy
development areas, and leased to developers by the SEA starting from 2020 over
a period of 5 years to develop as commercial timber cum fuel wood plantations.

development areas, and leased to developers by the SEA starting from 2020 over
a period of 5 years to develop as commercial timber cum fuel wood plantations.

5c At least 10,000 hectare of unproductive land will be prescribed as biomass energy
development areas, and leased to developers by the SEA starting from 2020 over
a period of 5 years to develop as commercial timber cum fuel wood plantations.

5d Biomass supply chains in five regions will be supported through improved
collection of biomass residue, mixed cropping and certification of sustainable
extraction for a three-year duration until they reach commercialisation through a
pilot project by 2020 by the SEA.

5d Biomass supply chains in five regions will be supported through improved
collection of biomass residue, mixed cropping and certification of sustainable
extraction for a three-year duration until they reach commercialisation through a
pilot project by 2020 by the SEA.

Households across Niger 
rely heavily on traditional biomass to meet 
their basic energy needs.

Households across Niger 
rely heavily on traditional biomass to meet 
their basic energy needs.

Households across Niger 
rely heavily on traditional biomass to meet 
their basic energy needs.

For Niger, 
increasing electricity access and making 
a transition from inefficient biomass use 
is not only about having the resources 
available.

For Niger, 
increasing electricity access and making 
a transition from inefficient biomass use 
is not only about having the resources 
available.

The share of renewables 
as a proportion of TPES remains negligible 
at less than 1%, assuming that all biomass is 
non-renewable - which is not the case.

The share of renewables 
as a proportion of TPES remains negligible 
at less than 1%, assuming that all biomass is 
non-renewable - which is not the case.

However, electricity 
access in Niger remains low at about 24% 
and almost all the population relies on the 
unsustainable use of traditional biomass

However, electricity 
access in Niger remains low at about 24% 
and almost all the population relies on the 
unsustainable use of traditional biomass

Niger lacks adequate information on forest 
cover and biomass potential.

Niger lacks adequate information on forest 
cover and biomass potential.

The production of biogas by 
anaerobic fermentation of agricultural and 
animal biomass (anaerobic digestion) has 
also been used in Niger, but no numbers 
have been recorded.

The production of biogas by 
anaerobic fermentation of agricultural and 
animal biomass (anaerobic digestion) has 
also been used in Niger, but no numbers 
have been recorded.

The Nigerien government considers energy 
a cross-cutting challenge, given the heavy 
reliance on traditional biomass using 
unsustainable appliances, increasing power 
demand for economic transformation and 
less than 2% rural energy access.

The Nigerien government considers energy 
a cross-cutting challenge, given the heavy 
reliance on traditional biomass using 
unsustainable appliances, increasing power 
demand for economic transformation and 
less than 2% rural energy access.

The Nigerien government considers energy 
a cross-cutting challenge, given the heavy 
reliance on traditional biomass using 
unsustainable appliances, increasing power 
demand for economic transformation and 
less than 2% rural energy access.

The Nigerien government considers energy 
a cross-cutting challenge, given the heavy 
reliance on traditional biomass using 
unsustainable appliances, increasing power 
demand for economic transformation and 
less than 2% rural energy access.

At the same time, a new 
generation of advanced and more effective 
biomass cookstoves is showing signs of 
commercial viability.

At the same time, a new 
generation of advanced and more effective 
biomass cookstoves is showing signs of 
commercial viability.

This biomass sector has delivered excellent 
results and supported rural development 
in various parts of Asia.

results and supported rural development 
in various parts of Asia.

#1 INTRODUCTION
1.1 Energy Supply
Energy supply in Sri Lanka is mainly based on three primary resources, namely, biomass, petroleum and
hydroelectricity.

#1 INTRODUCTION
1.1 Energy Supply
Energy supply in Sri Lanka is mainly based on three primary resources, namely, biomass, petroleum and
hydroelectricity.

This is mainly due to limitations in further hydropower
development owing to lower economic viability of exploiting the remaining large hydropower sites and limited use of biomass
with gradually increasing standard of living of the population.

This is mainly due to limitations in further hydropower
development owing to lower economic viability of exploiting the remaining large hydropower sites and limited use of biomass
with gradually increasing standard of living of the population.
Biomass and wind are also emerging as significant forms of commercial energy.
Biomass and wind are also emerging as significant forms of commercial energy.

* Biomass-based energy projects will be developed in areas where land resources are available, enabling new
industrial activities in such areas, empahasising on creating rural income generation avenues.

* Biomass-based energy projects will be developed in areas where land resources are available, enabling new
industrial activities in such areas, empahasising on creating rural income generation avenues.

* Initiatives of other sectors and institutions to convert biomass and other waste to energy will be encouraged
and supported where appropriate.

* Initiatives of other sectors and institutions to convert biomass and other waste to energy will be encouraged
and supported where appropriate.

Every effort will be made to replace
petroleum-based fuesl with indegenous biomass fueld in industrial thermal applications by encouraging such
fuel switching initiatives through appropriate incentive, including facilitation of access to green funding
such as CDM.

Every effort will be made to replace
petroleum-based fuesl with indegenous biomass fueld in industrial thermal applications by encouraging such
fuel switching initiatives through appropriate incentive, including facilitation of access to green funding
such as CDM.

petroleum-based fuesl with indegenous biomass fueld in industrial thermal applications by encouraging such
fuel switching initiatives through appropriate incentive, including facilitation of access to green funding
such as CDM.

petroleum-based fuesl with indegenous biomass fueld in industrial thermal applications by encouraging such
fuel switching initiatives through appropriate incentive, including facilitation of access to green funding
such as CDM.

Based Electricity in the Grid
* NRE Resources include small-scale hydropower, biomass including dendro power, biogas and waste, solar
power and wind power.

Based Electricity in the Grid
* NRE Resources include small-scale hydropower, biomass including dendro power, biogas and waste, solar
power and wind power.

* Commercial development of biomass will be encouraged and facilitated as a new rural industry, allowing
rural poor to engage in fuelwool farming and participate in the mainstream economic activity by supplying
electricity to urban load centres.

* Commercial development of biomass will be encouraged and facilitated as a new rural industry, allowing
rural poor to engage in fuelwool farming and participate in the mainstream economic activity by supplying
electricity to urban load centres.

a period of 5 years to develop as commercial timber cum fuel wood plantations.

development areas, and leased to developers by the SEA starting from 2020 over
a period of 5 years to develop as commercial timber cum fuel wood plantations.

5d Biomass supply chains in five regions will be supported through improved
collection of biomass residue, mixed cropping and certification of sustainable
extraction for a three-year duration until they reach commercialisation through a
pilot project by 2020 by the SEA.

a cross-cutting challenge, given the heavy 
reliance on traditional biomass using 
unsustainable appliances, increasing power 
demand for economic transformation and 
less than 2% rural energy access.

#1 INTRODUCTION
1.1 Energy Supply
Energy supply in Sri Lanka is mainly based on three primary resources, namely, biomass, petroleum and
hydroelectricity.

#1 INTRODUCTION
1.1 Energy Supply
Energy supply in Sri Lanka is mainly based on three primary resources, namely, biomass, petroleum and
hydroelectricity.

expanding the use and local production of fuel-efficient stoves.
